entry.title: Five-Pavilion Bridge (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that Yangzhou's Five-Pavilion Bridge (pictured) was built by salt merchants to welcome the Qianlong Emperor?

entry.title: society (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that the use of trade in prehistoric society may have given humans an evolutionary advantage over Neanderthals?

entry.title: Hannah Grae (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that the British rock musician Hannah Grae went viral online with an anti-sexual harassment parody of Aqua's "Barbie Girl"?

entry.title: 2024 College Football Playoff National Championship (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that Michigan's victory in the 2024 College Football Playoff National Championship marked their first outright national championship since 1948?

entry.title: cherry blossom (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that the cherry blossom was used symbolically in Japanese World War II propaganda, with falling petals representing "young soldiers' sacrifice for the emperor"?

entry.title: I Want You (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that the music video for SB19's "I Want You" showed scenes of the boy band shot underwater?

entry.title: Wendell Steavenson (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that the journalist Wendell Steavenson's book Circling the Square covers the events of the 2011–2013 Egyptian crisis, which were centered around Cairo's Tahrir Square?

entry.title: optics inspired by lobster eyes (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that lenses for telescopes are being designed using optics inspired by lobster eyes?
